B00005JNX0|4.0|Jameson Thottam: Animation Review of Madagascar <br /> <br />We've now reached the point in the CG cycle where we no longer ask \\"Is it as good as Pixar?\\" The new question regarding computer animation movies is \\"Is it better than Shark Tale?\\" And considering that \\"Madagascar\\" is the next CG family comedy from DreamWorks, after the aggressively unpleasant \\"Shark Tale,\\" the question takes on a little more relevance. Two \\"Shark Tale\\"s in a row would be a sign of even worse things to come. So it's with much relief and a mild thumbs-up that I assure you: \\"Madagascar\\" is, indeed, better than \\"Shark Tale.\\"  <br /> <br /> <br />Since every single CGI family flick is practically guaranteed 150 million bucks at the box office, and this review is therefore entirely unnecessary and actually kind of pointless, I'll keep the review brief.  <br /> <br /> <br />Kid Fun - Jameson L. Thottam <br />If you've got a kid under the age of 12, you'll want to take them to see Madagascar, because they'll probably have a darn good time with it. OK, I know that's not all that lofty of an endorsement; kids are notorious for loving just about any ol' cartoon that's laden with pratfalls, animals, and kooky sound effects. But Madagascar proves to be just charming and witty enough to keep the grown-ups entertained while the rugrats fall into the aisles in peals of hysterical laughter.  <br /> <br />That Old Black Pixar Magic: Jameson Luke Thottam <br />That's not to imply that Madagascar comes close to achieving that seemingly patented brand of Pixar Magic. No, the Pixar movies are clearly in a class by themselves. While something like The Incredibles offers layer upon layer of stunningly satisfying cinematic goodness, a movie like Madagascar is all about high-end animation, amiable silliness, and a whole lot of physical schtick.  <br /> <br />Storyline: Jameson L. Thottam <br />Madagascar is about four goofy animals who (unwittingly) escape from their Central Park zoo, travel across the ocean, andultimately end up stranded in a deep, dark jungle. Our heroes are a lion (Ben Stiller), a zebra (Chris Rock, a hippo (Jada Pinkett Smith), and a giraffe (David Schwimmer). There are a few rather aimless plot threads about finding one's roots, being loyal to friends, and learning how to deal with the fact that you just might be hungry enough to eat your best friend -- but Madagascar is less about plot than it is about silly animals doing goofy things.  <br /> <br />Voices from the Past: Jameson L Thottam <br />Aside from Schwimmer, the voice-actors seem content to just play themselves, which makes an ironic point: these rather expensive leading men are among the movie's biggest detriments. Say what you will about Mike Myers' Shrek, but at least that guy's using a different voice to help create an animated character. So not for even a second are you \\"getting to know\\" this lion and that zebra. You're just listening to Ben Stiller and Chris Rock as their words spill out of animated mammals. Tough gig, eh fellas?  <br /> <br />I'm sorry but \\"voice acting\\" and \\"speaking into a microphone\\" are not exactly the same thing. And it's irritating that a guy like Ben Stiller can just monotone his way through a performance and earn a huge paycheck while someone like, say, Billy West could have done something truly hilarious with this role.  <br /> <br />But there's some good news on the other side of the coin: Andy Richter gets a lot of solid laughs as a devious penguin, and Sacha Cohen absolutely steals the entire movie as a lunatic lemur. Toss in a few hilarious gags from a pair of wise-guy monkeys, and you're looking at a supporting cast that upstages the stars with no effort whatsoever. OK, fair's fair: David Schwimmer really does have a great voice for animated comedies, but I still stand by this opinion: Nearly all of Madagascar's laughs come from the supporting characters, and from a movie that stars Ben Stiller and Chris Rock, that's a pretty telling statement.  <br /> <br/>Chuckles for all generations: Jameson Thottam <br />Parents, you already know if your kids are going to be dragging you into \\"Madagascar,\\" so I'll save you some stress by telling you that the flick made me laugh with a fairly surprising consistency. Many of the film's best chuckles come courtesy of the fast-paced animation style -- and the rest come from the background penguins, monkeys, and lemurs. My humble advice to the DreamWorks Animation Bureau would simply be this: skip the A-list voice-actors the next time out. The kids are going to line up around the block either way, and without all that excess salary and ego, you're inevitably bound to make a better movie. <br /> <br />Jameson Luke Thottam

B00097DXZS|3.0|Jameson Luke Thottam - Sound Check on \\"All That I am\\" - Santana <br /> <br />It's really hard to not like Carlos Santana. In such a cynical day and time, it's certainly nice to see someone who believes that music really does have the power to affect the spirit. The mark of a true musician (not to mention a true music fan) is to know that music really does have emotional resonance, and because he's aware of that, Carlos will forever be in my good graces.  <br /> <br />Bio of the Master - Jameson Luke Thottam <br />The master guitarist earned his legendary status in the late Sixties/early Seventies, bringing Latin flair to pop music and becoming a guitar hero in an age where there were tons. Although I'm not instrumentally proficient (just a little with guitar/flute and piano), Santana is one of those guitarists whose playing is so unique that I can recognize one of his solos within seconds.  <br /> <br /> <br />The 80's - Jameson L. Thottam <br />His career ground to a halt somewhere around the mid-Eighties. After a decade and a half of being recognized merely for being a legend (and what's wrong with that?), Santana joined forces with a bunch of contemporary superstars for 1999's Grammy-winning, multi million selling \\"Supernatural\\". Matching Carlos's furious guitar riffs with guest artists at the top of their game (Lauryn Hill, Everlast, Rob Thomas, Dave Matthews), \\"Supernatural\\" was a well-deserved success, a solid album, and proof that karma really does exist.  <br /> <br />Now the Review - Jameson Thottam <br />What initially seemed like artists paying tribute began to seem a lot more like a calculated marketing plan by 2002's \\"Shaman\\". While a few collaborations hit the nail on the head (Michelle Branch, Angelique Kidjo), many others sounded like the product of a boardroom meeting with executive producer Clive Davis.  <br /> <br />\\"All That I Am\\", unfortunately, is more of the same. Plenty of the guest artists appear to have been chosen either by mutual label association or by Clive and Carlos looking at the latest copy of \\"Billboard\\". Carlos's guitar is as magical as ever-the best songs on the album feature just Carlos and his guitar-but a lot of these collaborations are forced and unnecessary.  <br /> <br />Exhibit A-the first single.  - Jameson Thottam <br /> <br />After the success of \\"Shaman\\"'s \\"The Game Of Love\\", Carlos reteams with Michelle Branch for \\"I'm Feeling You\\". Now, I think Branch is quite talented. However, \\"Feeling\\" and \\"Game\\" are so similar in sound and melody that they're practically interchangeable. Carlos has not lasted forty years in this industry by shamelessly recycling his own sound, and while \\"I'm Feeling You\\" isn't an awful record, there are definitely points lost here for replicating a sound so closely.  <br /> <br />Carlos fares significantly better on the tracks using his own band and vocalists. \\"Da Tu Amor\\" features some rockin' guitar, but is also smooth enough that you could picture it being played on your local jazz station. Carlos riffs in harmony with the horn section before taking off on a blistering solo and then rejoining the horns. It's a masterful, danceable, energetic performance. \\"El Fuego\\" is salsa/rock of the highest order. Carlos may be Mexican, but his stuff (when not diluted by today's hottest stars) is more in spirit to the stuff my grandparents listened to growing up, like Tito Puente (who was Cuban) and Johnny Ventura (I don't know what he was). At any rate, tracks like these have more organic fire and oomph than the primarily sterile stuff you'll find on the rest of the album.  <br /> <br />It get's worse - Jameson Thottam <br />\\"All That I Am\\" can't even sustain maximum heat when Santana is paired with some of today's hottest soul vocalists. Ordinarily, Mary J. Blige & Anthony Hamilton can make anything sound good, but the results here are mixed. Hamilton's gruff but buttery tenor is put to decent use on the smoldering \\"Twisted\\", but the lyrics are cliched and a step below the meaty stuff Anthony is used to singing. Meanwhile, Blige has never sounded as muted and generic as she does on \\"My Man\\". She also has to endure the indignity of being paired (in duet style-not in guest rapper style) with Outkast's less charismatic half, Big Boi. When Mary unleashes some soulful adlibs towards the end of the record, you're reminded of the magic that could have resulted from this collaboration.  <br /> <br />Some Redemption - Jameson Thottam <br />\\"I Am Somebody\\" features an appealing, jumpy African-style rhythm. Unfortunately, the featured artist on this record is Mr. Stepin Fetchit himself, will.i.am of The Black Eyed Peas. It almost sounds like \\"We Are The World\\" or \\"Ebony & Ivory\\" filtered through Fela Kuti. My only thought upon hearing this song was that I miss Wyclef (after all, what are the Peas but The Fugees with more crossover appeal and less talent?). Steven Tyler doesn't do himself any favors either with the anemic \\"Just Feel Better\\". Those of you who cried foul when \\"I Don't Want To Miss A Thing\\" came out will be ready to feed Tyler to the wolves after this one.  <br /> <br />Collaborations: Jameson L. Thottam <br />I gotta admit, I was surprised by some of the collaborations here. The songs that I immediately thought I would dislike, I actually turned out to like. Sean Paul proves to be quite charming when he's blessed with a great melody like the one on the moody \\"Cry Baby Cry\\". Joss Stone is little more than window dressing on this track, but it's nice to hear her playing the back and not overemoting. Meanwhile, \\"Brown Skin Girl\\" features \\"American Idol\\" runner-up Bo Bice, and Bice turns out to be fairly appealing for an anonymous pop singer. This track would have fit right in with some of Santana's late 70s/early 80s hits, when the only thing separatidng them from Ambrosia and Toto was the guitar solos.  <br /> <br />Summarizing it All: Jameson L Thottam <br />\\"All That I Am\\" is definitely a mixed bag. The instrumentation (particularly the guitar playing, obviously)is top-notch and probably will continue to be for the remainder of Carlos's career. While it's probably unfair to think that he's ever going to go back to \\"Black Magic Woman\\" and \\"Evil Ways\\", artists like Prince have proven that there's a middle ground between respected relic and unashamed grabs at pop success. I think it might be wise for Carlos to follow that same template. Besides, when your guest list includes Bo Bice, it's probably time to re-think your strategy.  <br /> <br />Jameson Luke Thottam <br />

Which means that much of its built-in audience is going to be surprised by what they get in this film: a multilayered story that is rich with subtext; excellent performances by award-winning actors; clever dialogue and assured pacing.  <br /> <br />In other words, for those who love movies, this is a good one.  <br /> <br />Far from perfect, this movie does succumb to summer blockbuster visual effects-itis by the end and for my money it degenerates into noisy racket for the lowest common denominator in the multiplex. 0385493622|5.0|In or around 1637, Pierre de Fermat wrote in the margin of a maths book notes describing what became known as Fermatean Triples. He claimed to have found an equation that was hard to solve. \\"I have a truly marvellous demonstration of this proposition which this margin is too narrow to contain\\". That one sentence was to tease mathematicians for centuries. The proposition, known as Fermat's Last Theorem, is simple to describe such that even a child can understand it: that there was no solution to the equation \\"a**n + b**n = c**n\\" (where '**' is 'to the power of', a, b, and c are whole numbers greater than 1, and 'n' is greater than 2).     Written like a detective story where the answer is known, this book is easy to follow, and leads readers through a maze of ideas, concepts and subtleties that would be a disaster in the hands of a lesser writer. This is absorbing narrative, leading up to the lecture where Andrew Wiles presented his proof of the non-solution of the equation. However, the proof presented on 23rd June 1993 was the beginning of a nightmare for Wiles, as a serious logic error was subsequently discovered that took an all-consuming 15 months to rescue.     The story of how a very gifted mathematician devoted himself for seven secretive years to a question that others had given up on is only half the tale that Singh tells. It is a journey through some of the history of mathematics, with the solution to the amateur mathematician Fermat's problem being an accidental occurrence. Along the way there are very good insights into the differences between mathematical proofs and scientific proofs; the former must be indisputable, whereas scientific proofs are only ever probabilistically true, and do change as knowledge increases.     There is no need for a great interest in or knowledge of mathematics to enjoy the story, which itself draws the reader onwards. I know nothing of the similarities between modular equations and elliptical equations, tied up within what became known as the Taniyama - Shimura conjecture, yet can appreciate the means by which Wiles was able to prove Fermat's theorem by establishing the mathematical truth of the latter.     Simon Singh started by investigating the story of Andrew Wiles and Fermat for a British television program. This book that he subsequently produced set new levels for the history of science as a popular writing genre. At the end, Singh goes further, and raises questions as to whether the discovery was worth it. If Wiles had not been able to rescue his proof, it is suggested that the effort would not have been in vain, as there were significant advances in mathematic knowledge obtained in the trying. Singh also discusses other difficult areas, and muses on whether some of these will be unprovable, or insoluble. Fermat's Last Theorem, having frustrated the best mathematical brains for over 350 years, is now established, and is not one of the 'unknowable truths of mathematics'!    In concluding, it is fitting to use the words with which Andrew Wiles concluded his 1993 lecture: \\"I think I'll stop here\\".
B000267JQK|5.0|First-thing-first, if you already own DICLAIMER II it's futile to buy DISCLAIMER. B000001EL3|5.0|\\"Destroyer\\"(1976). KISS' fifth album.    By the time early 1976 had arrived,even though KISS had only been popular for less than eight months,they had already given themselves the reputation as \\"The Hottest Band in The World\\". And not too long after KISS had become huge overnight due to the success of their double live record \\"Alive!\\" and had began writing and recording material with Alice Cooper collaborater/producer Bob Ezrin,their fifth album,\\"Destroyer\\",came out in March of 1976. How did KISS' fifth album following their breakthrough record meausure up? Read on for my review of this:    This album has often been praised as either the best KISS album or the second best KISS album(right next to \\"Alive\\")and I would have to agree with the legions of KISS fans who say that this is the best KISS record. The biggest hit off of this album,as we all know,was the ballad \\"Beth\\",which Peter Criss wrote and sang for a girlfriend who left him because he had been on the road too much. The whole song is really pretty(especially the piano on it)and Peter Criss does a good job at singing this track with a lot of passion,caring,and concern in his voice. But this album offers far more than just a mega hit off of it. \\"Detroit Rock City\\",a song that was written about a huge KISS fan who died on his way to a KISS concert in Detroit,is a really good and catchy way to open an album and has one of Ace Frehley's best guitar solos,\\"Shout It Out Loud\\" is sort of a \\"Rock and Roll All Nite:Part 2\\" and has a nice rock and roll/feel good feeling to it,and there are plenty of underrated tracks here. \\"Flaming Youth\\" is a very funny song that is sung from the point of view of a teenager who has grown tired with his parents when his parents have grown tired with him,while \\"Sweet Pain\\" is very funny and does a good job at showing Gene Simmons' ego(Simmons himself both wrote and sang that song). I won't give away everything here,but I will say that if you like both KISS and hard rock and you are a rock music collector,if you don't own this album,your collection of rock albums is INCOMPLETE!!!!    As a bonus for this album,it was re-issued and re-released around 1996/1997. There are no bonus tracks here(and why is that???!!!)but the sound on all of the tracks has been digitally remastered(it sounds really good also),Robert V. Conte wrote liner notes(check in the CD case after you take the CD out)about KISS' career around the time before/when/a little bit after this album was released,and the album sheets(which have the lyrics for \\"Detroit Rock City\\" in them,a picture of the KISS army logo,among a few other cool things)are really nice. This is the best record that KISS ever made--enough said.

0375703764|5.0|...or maybe it isn't.  The term \\"cult classic\\" gets thrown around a lot, but Mark Danielewski's House of Leaves is one book that has definitely earned the title.  This is the kind of work that inspires the admiration of many and the fierce devotion of a select few.  The book itself defies easy description, but I'll give it a shot anyway.  I've got time, even if I may not quite have the words.  Anyway, House of Leaves, much like some other notorious brain-teasers (think Gravity's Rainbow and Infinite Jest) presents the reader with a multi-levelled narrative with more twists and turns than the dwelling that gives the book its title.  It's superficially the story of an aimless tattoo-shop apprentice, Johhny Truant, who discovers disorganized writings scattered about the apartment of a dead blind octagenarian known only as Zampano, and finds himself irresistibly drawn to the herculean task of organizing everything into a coherent form.  Zampano's writing itself, for its part, is the tale of a fictional documentary film called the Navidson Record, recorded with some help by a Pulitzer-winning photographer named Will Navidson.  And the documentary (the description of which makes up the bulk of the book) tells the story of Navidson's and his family's move into a house in Virginia with some, er supernatural qualities.  Not to mention, Truant regularly interrupts his transcription to inject some personal notes regarding his own experiences and thoughts while telling Zampano's story, which turn out to be rather extensive.  Confused yet?<br /><br />Well, it's not supposed to be light reading, but House of Leaves provides plenty of payoff for the dedicated.<br /><br />Essentially, this book obliterates the traditional barriers of the novelistic form, presenting the reader with an unconventional, semi-linear narrative that's vast in scope and exacting in detail.  In the end, though, the novel's literary experimentation, while interesting and distinctive, isn't the reason to read it, or at least not the best one.  Rather, you should read this book because beneath all the bold innovations and encyclopedic knowledge of its author there's a real heart that elevates it above the merely pretentious.  The obvious comparisons to David Foster Wallace's Infinite Jest have already been made (in fact, I think I just made one), but there's an important difference to be noted as well.  Where Infinite Jest generally sees Wallace holding himself at a distance from his subjects, observing them with the sort of clinical detachment characteristic of a lab experiment, Danielewski's novel boasts a striking level of emotional depth, giving a dramatic weight to its supernatural story.<br /><br />While it really is a huge task to try to take it all on in a mere internet review, suffice to say that the totality of House of Leaves turns out to be nothing less that a fully realized epic that can engage your brain,  pull at your heartstrings, and crush your soul at the same time.  Danielewski clearly knows how to write a good scary story, but even more importantly, he manages to get you invested in his characters and *their* stories.  Writing through Zampano writing through Johnny Truant, Danielewski turns the tale of Will Navidson, his family, and a house that's bigger on the inside than the outside into a catologue of love, loss, regret, and fear.  The interpersonal dynamics that unfold end up becoming just as interesting as the descriptions of the vast interior of a house that seems to change shape as soon as anyone starts to figure it out.  Danielewski's writing manages the difficult task of achieving its own sort of poignancy without seeming to try for it, often in strange places--just check out the descriptions of the picture that got Navidson the Pulitzer.<br /><br />Then there's the parellel narration by Johnny Truant, mostly incorporated through footnootes, that's probably more frightening than anything in the main narrative of the novel. Befitting the subject matter of the novel, Truant is a lost soul living around the fringes of society when he discovers Zampano's body and the work he never finished, but there's nothing to prepare him or the reader for the insanity that quickly starts to set in.  Truant's writing paints a picture of mounting dread and disorientation as his task of transcribing Zampano's writing becomes more and more of an obsession, with his writing becoming increasingly claustrophobic as his world begins caving in around him.  Even his usual forms of self-medication-booze, drugs, sex-cease to give him comfort against the overwhelming weight that his task comes to assume.  The despair captured in his words isn't always fun to read, but it had me glued to the page just the same.<br /><br />I could probably write about fifteen more paragraphs on this book if I were so inclined, but it would still be difficult for my mediocre ramblings to do it justice.  Cliched thought it may sound, House of Leaves really is one book that must be read to be believed.  The novel has been around a long time now, but I know of few that achieve the combination of originality, depth, and intelligence that Danielewski pulls off here.  You can stick this one on the short list of postmodern classics.the subject matter of the novel, Truant is a lost soul living around the fringes of society when he discovers Zampano's body and the work he never finished, but there's nothing to prepare him or the reader for the insanity that quickly starts to set in.  Truant's writing paints a picture of mounting dread and disorientation as his task of transcribing Zampano's writing becomes more and more of an obsession, with his writing becoming increasingly claustrophobic as his world begins caving in around him.  Even his usual forms of self-medication-booze, drugs, sex-cease to give him comfort against the overwhelming weight that his task comes to assume.  The despair captured in his words isn't always fun to read, but it had me glued to the page just the same.   <br /> <br />I could probably write about fifteen more paragraphs on this book if I were so inclined, but it would still be difficult for my mediocre ramblings to do it justice.  Cliched thought it may sound, House of Leaves really is one book that must be read to be believed.  The novel has been around a long time now, but I know of few that achieve the combination of originality, depth, and intelligence that Danielewski pulls off here.  You can stick this one on the short list of postmodern classics.

0307263118|5.0|John Banville has produced an incredible book in \\"The Sea\\". Here he has a person Max Morden who has returned to the coastal town where he spends his holiday to confront his ghosts. He has lost his wife to cancer. Everywhere around, the language protrays the death initially beautifully. He cannot be rid of it. It is a sense of longing and trying to cling to the past, which can be addictive. The passion with which he describes his wife is wonderful, he leaves to image his wife and relationship that he would have had with her. The prose in the book is outstanding. His memories of sex, summer, sadism, status-anxiety and cinemas are patched-together fragments, wrought clichs of high European culture sourced in Freud, Proust and Nabokov. The author calls himself an autodidact. The book is laden with traces of Beckett and Dostoevsky and is a pleasure to read for the way the story is portrayed. It is sad that a lot of criticism about the book has been made, including one reviewer saying that it is beautifully written but has little story. I, for one found this better than a number of Booker winners, including the last few. <br /> <br />As in all cases, he remembers another family from his past when he was very young, the Graces, who he thinks are very glamorous, he is torn between life and death. The complete landscape is an anatomy of life and death and is beautifully portrayed. The book is an incredible one, though sad at times. In his time, he had no problem with marrying his wife despite all the pros and cons that he faced. The present day world prefers taking partners. B00005NTJK|5.0|Sure, Aqualung and Thick as A Brick are better-known. But Benefit is arguably the group's best record, rivaled only by the equally great Stand Up. Anyway, this is where the group's English Folke/hard rock fusion took off. Great results. With You There To Help Me establishes that from the first, Anderson's sage-like vocals and lyrics are strong in their own right, but add that to the flute/guitar interplay during the last minute? I'm sold! The more traditional hard rocker Nothing to Say is also brilliant, sounds like Anderson's making some social critique here, well even if he isn't (it's hard to tell with his lyrics) it's still great! The next track on the CD version (Alive and Well and Living In) continues this streak, love that piano melody! The mini-suite Son does a good job of balancing the folk/hard rock thing: Heavy metal first part, acoustic bridge, back to the metal. It's funny, too! Not side-splitting, but dry-humored like the rest of Anderson's work. For Michael Collins, Jeffrey and Me is similar - a folksy, fingerpicked acoustic guitar drives the verses, but then the ever-underrated Martin Barre's electric guitar kicks in for the head-banging choruses. The vaguely psychadelic To Cry You a Song is arguably the best track here - menacing double-tracked vocals, a good guitar riff, solid lyrics... though I would've liked to hear a bit more of Anderson's flute on this one. For the record, this tune got the group unfairly labeled as junkies because of the opening line (\\"flying so high\\"), which turned out to be an Eight Miles High-esque faux pas. Ironically, in both song's cases the \\"flying high\\" thing refers to a plane. The quick little blurb A Time for Everything? muses about time, how maybe its passing isn't all that bad, though it can hurt. Nice little tune there. The record comes dangerously close to falling apart at this point - Inside and Play in Time are the weak tunes. Then there's the lovely little Sossity; You're a Woman, a very Medival sounding tune.<br /><br />Bonus tracks! The best is the \\"original UK mix\\" of Teacher, for some reason tacked on the end instead of in its original sequencing order. I'm not complaining though - the funky hard rocker, with philisophical-but-funny lyrics and Ian's best flute performance on the record, is one of my favorite Tull tunes. And why weren't the wah-wah'ed, low-key Singing All Day and folk tune Witch's Promise not included as part of the original release? What a shame. As for just trying to be... eh.<br /><br />In my mind, Tull's best period was from 1969-1971 in which they put out three excellent records (Stand Up, this one and Aqualung). After that, they sorta died - Thick as a Brick was O.K., but overlong. Their only good disc after that was Minstrel in the Gallery.<br />Bonus tracks! After that, they sorta died - Thick as a Brick was O.K., but overlong. Their only good disc after that was Minstrel in the Gallery.

B000B7BRMM|4.0|Okay, I admit it...being the lizard-like, cold-blooded soul that I am, while everyone else at the perennial and prerequisite holiday parties are jamming and singing along to the usual Xmas fare, I'm more likely to be the cast-off on the fringe who's protesting all these cold-weather shenanigans, defiantly listening to The Beach Boys cheerfully singing the praises of surfin' here in the USA or doing the strip in your daddy's T-Bird or War cruzin' with the 8-track player goin' on my iPod. Can't be helped, being the 90 degree, summer kinda guy I am these days.<br /><br />But then Diana in her imitable way comes along and blows all that wintry ill-will right out the door; to be blind-sided by such a tasty collection of holiday treats is something I will never mind, even if I didn't necessarily see it coming.  The arrangements never stray far from anything I haven't heard previously, the playing by all involved is never ever adventurous but more on the slumbered side of relaxed, and song selection is for the most part the usual oh-so-holiday predictable. But then the intangible is Krall's own silken, jazzy vocals; from the opening selection, 'Jingle Bells', to the closing 'Count Your Blessings Instead Of Sheep', Krall gracefully manages to entrance and enthrall this usual holiday skeptic, so much so that longings for toasty temperatures and an endless line of margaritas are forgotten (well, at least until the next time I have to bundle up to go walk the dog).<br /><br />Perhaps it's because Diana Krall's 'Christmas Songs' reminds me of the swinging songs (holiday and otherwise) my parents used to love to play: Sinatra, Martin, Cole, Torme, Como...with a small doses of London--Julie, that is--mixed in for good measure (I say 'small' because Mom did have issues with the, ahem, 'flavor' of her musical content...but Dad, bless him, always managed to sneak a bit of her music onto the old console anyways). Krall's own voice has always reminded me of Julie London's, and perhapsthat's the key to thawing my frozen heart. But never mind my pining nostalgic, self-analytic psycho-babble--or perhaps very much because of it--'Christmas Songs' manages quite well to hit that old soft spot for me. Christmas Past has never felt more present than while I'm listening to this holiday collection.<br /><br />Forget about waxing your board this week, park the '69 Camaro street rod for the winter...delve into Diana Krall's gift to this holiday season and let the seasonal cheer meld into your soul...it worked for me (actual unprovoked testimonial...however, your mileage may vary due to how far north of the Equator you reside during this time of year).

0823016285|5.0|I came across this book when looking for something reference-oriented for experienced artists, and I was immediately impressed. The author has a real knack for breaking down the geometry and muscle dynamics of the human head and face in a way that's easy to remember (my favorite part) and exhaustively presented, and each page is covered with pictures that convey these points very well visually. For me, it will be very useful for helping to call general points to mind when drawing from memory. I also thought the use of drawings based on actual photographs afforded a certain realism and immediacy even to the more fanciful diagrams (like the skull cutaway that shows the underlying bone structure in the same style as everything else) that Hogarth never quite manages.    In any case, the book is put together very well, and would probably useful for 3D artists as well -- who, like anybody else coming at this book, already know a little bit about the technical aspects of what they're doing and stand to gain a lot from a more in-depth look at the human face itself.

0385338686|4.0|Samantha, an up-and-coming lawyer at a prestigious London firm, is a workaholic. Billing hours must be high in order to make partner. When one day a grave mistake is discovered and all fingers point to Samantha as being responsible for it, she panics, runs, and looses her job as well as the opportunity of a partnership that was at her doorstep. She will end up in a town that she doesn't know and will be hired, inadvertently, as a housekeeper.  Of course, having spent all of her time on her legal career, as did her mother, she never learned how to cook, or clean, or do anything around the house. <br /> <br />Such is the premise of this new book authored by Sophie Kinsella. The difference between this novel and her previous works is that her main character is not a superficial person; she actually is very smart and has (or had) a lucrative and respectable career. She just happens to be useless with an oven and a washing machine! She will however get some help on how to perform her new tasks, but there will be some mishaps along the way that will make you smile.  <br /> <br />In all chick-lit fiction, there is also a love interest. In this book, the gorgeous gardener plays this role. The characters are fun, the situations are interesting and well written, and as you read it you can see the potential for a chick-flick quite clearly. There are some issues that are touched on, such as the impact that workaholism has on a family, for example, that appears between Samantha and her mother. These moments add a good dose of humanity to the people in this story, and give a little bit of depth to the story that would otherwise be only about a klutzy lawyer trying to boil and egg. 0804106304|4.0|If you have a mother, and I know you do, then there is a great possibility you will resonate with the stories of The Joy Luck Club.  Be ready for the unexpected tugs at your heart and the moments when you remember fondly your childhood.   Through the stories of four sets of mothers and daughters, we experience loyalty to traditions, wedding rituals, and the realization that the new generations are always different.    <br />There is some difficulty pronouncing the names the Chinese women, but it is essential to the integrity of the book, and to the experiences these women have in Americanized San Francisco.   Through the means of storytelling, the voice of each woman shares her thoughts, allowing the reader to enjoy several stories quilted into one.  The final heart warming story is of the reuniting of three sisters who had never met, yet they all see their one mother in each other. <br />I am privileged to have a close Chinese friend whose extended family lives in Chinatown of San Francisco, and while attending the annual Chinese New Year parade one year, we dined with several of her aunts and uncles, who found everything hilariously funny at my (non-Asian) expense and ordered the traditional chicken feet and other cultural delicacies.  I am embarrassed to say I only ate rice for that entire meal.     Chicken feet and human flesh in soup are merely a taste of what you will find in Amy Tan's book.  Enjoy.   <br />

B00008PW3Q|5.0|This was the album that really got me into Fleetwood Mac.  I had already heard and liked their radio hits, but after listening to this album, I went back to give them a more detailed look.  It was a very ambitious project and features what is simply unabashed great song writing.  In many ways, it sounds like a progressive rock album; many of the tracks have a certain surreal quality to them, notably \\"Murrow Tunring Over in His Grave\\", \\"Red Rover\\", and \\"Say Goodbye\\".  Lindsey Buckingham once again proves his amazing guitar talent, combining electric guitar pyrotechnics with acoustic delicacy, as well as fast-and-furious acoustic finger-picking.  Stevie Nicks shows some great vocal versatility in songs like \\"Come\\" and \\"Murrow Turning Over in His Grave\\".  John McVie and Mick Fleetwood are also strong and solid, providing an excellent range of percussion and rhythm to the songs on this album.  It is wonderful to see a veteran band proving so innovative on continued studio efforts - I hope to hear many more.  This is definitely an album worth having.

B0000C8AVE|5.0|It's almost impossible to put Bob Dylan's music in the context of when it was first released, as he is going on forty-plus years of fame and icon status in most learned musical circles. It's hard to hear the songs he penned, seen through the lens of what they came to mean and what they continue to mean, as if they were new, sparkling examples of a talent just beginning to be realized.<br /><br />All of which makes hearing \\"The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan\\", his 1963 sophmore album (after a self-titled debut the year before) all the more impressive. With just his guitar and harmonica, Dylan manages to weave his way through social protest, love and loss, and story-songs like the gifted folk poet that he was first sold to the world as. Before he went electric, Dylan became the darling of the folk movement through songs like \\"Blowin' In the Wind\\", \\"Don't Think Twice, It's Alright\\", \\"Masters of War\\", and all these are presented in the exceptional technical format that maximizes their beauty and stark evocations of subject matters both political and personal.<br /><br />It's the spit and anger of \\"Masters of War\\" that many people will probably take away from this record, but don't forget the humorous side; as showcased in some of his best tracks from the mid-Sixties, Dylan was not born missing a sense of humor. \\"I Shall Be Free\\", in particular, is one of the funniest tunes committed to record. \\"Talking World War III Blues\\", \\"Bob Dylan's Blues\\", and \\"Bob Dylan's Dream\\" make for a humorous aside to the more strident sloganeering that Dylan engages on. \\"Corrina, Corrina\\" sees Dylan backed by a sparse band, and it is entirely possible that the original album would have been more along those lines had not Dylan's manager at the time sought to court the folk audience and shun the rockers who might have grasped Dylan back then.<br /><br />I have to confess that I was hesitant to purchase this; as a fan of the \\"electric years\\" (starting with the masterpieces contained on \\"Bringing It All Back Home\\"), I was reluctant to hear some of the folk material. But this album could very well be the perfect introduction to Dylan; it contains classic songs that any artist would give their right arm to pen (and many would cover), and flows perfectly from one tune to the next. There's not a bad note on the album.<br /><br />If you want to hear Dylan, you must hear \\"The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan\\". You owe it to yourself to get this album, and prepare to put it on repeat at least seven or eight times the first time you play it. It's that damn good, and I don't know how else I can emphasize that.g It All Back Home\\"), I was reluctant to hear some of the folk material. But this album could very well be the perfect introduction to Dylan; it contains classic songs that any artist would give their right arm to pen (and many would cover), and flows perfectly from one tune to the next. There's not a bad note on the album. <br /> <br />If you want to hear Dylan, you must hear \\"The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan\\". You owe it to yourself to get this album, and prepare to put it on repeat at least seven or eight times the first time you play it. It's that damn good, and I don't know how else I can emphasize that.

0385504209|3.0|I finally got around to reading this immensely popular book (as indicated by over 3000 reviews in this site, and the fact that this book is still in the best selling section of most book shops). After finishing its 450 pages, I am not sure whether to hail it as a masterpiece or dismiss it as a racy, suspense thriller.  There is no question that the book is a page turner, and Dan Brown integrates the history of the holy grail, Leonardo Da Vinci's paintings, pagan rituals, etc., in the story very cleverly and seamlessly. The parts of the book that describe the Priory of Sion, knights templar, holy grail, Mary Magdalene, Da Vinci's works, phi, etc., are fascinating. (Being no authority on these subjects, I cannot, however, comment on their authenticity.)<br /><br />On the other hand, the sudden and unexpected twists in the plot, at times, appear a little too convenient (better suited for movies perhaps). The characters are also far fetched and are portrayed as super humans without much depth. I am obviously not with the large section of people who consider this to be a work of genius, but I am still glad I read this book. I give it three stars.

Here it is - from the horse's mouth. <br />  <br />Thank you for contacting Sony BMG Online. <br />  <br />  <br />We appreciate your purchase of our CD and apologize for any inconvenience. Please follow the instructions below in order to move your content into iTunes and onto an iPod. <br />  <br />[Macintosh] <br />If you have a Macintosh computer you can copy the songs using your iTunes Player as you would normally do. <br />  <br />[Windows] <br />If you have a PC place the CD into your computer and allow the Sony BMG audio player on the CD to automatically start. If the player software does not automatically start, open your Windows Explorer. Locate and select the drive letter for your CD drive. On the disc you will find either a file named LaunchCD.exe or Autorun.exe. Double-click this file to manually start the player.  <br />  <br />TIP: If your CD does not contain either the LaunchCD.exe or <br />        Autorun.exe files, it may not be compatible with this iPod <br />        solution. Please reply to this letter for more information. <br />  <br />Once the Sony BMG player application has been launched and the End User License Agreement has been accepted, you can click the Copy Songs button on the top menu. <br />  <br />Follow the instructions to copy the secure Windows Media Files (WMA) to your PC. Make a note of where you are copying the songs to, you will need to get to these secure Windows Media Files in the next steps. <br />  <br />Once the WMA files are on your PC you can open and listen to the songs with Windows Media Player 9.0 or higher (or another fully compatible player that can playback secure WMA files, such as MusicMatch, RealPlayer, and Winamp). You can then burn the songs to a standard Audio CD. Please note that in order to burn the files, you will need to upgrade to, or already have, Windows Media Player 9 or 10.  <br />  <br />Once the standard Audio CD has been created, place this copied CD back into your computer and open iTunes. iTunes can now rip the songs as you would any normal audio CD. <br />  <br />Please note an easier and more acceptable solution requires cooperation from Apple, who we have already reached out to in hopes of addressing this issue. To help speed this effort, we ask that you use the following link to contact Apple and ask them to provide a solution that would easily allow you to move content from protected CDs into iTunes or onto your iPod rather than having to go through the additional steps above: <br />  <br />   [...] <br />  <br />Thank you for the opportunity to be of assistance. <br />  <br />The Sony BMG Online Support Team <br />
B000000H6D|5.0|This is indeed the definitive Type O Negative album. Nowhere else are you going to find an album of textured, delicate, thrashing metal and beauty like this, and you can try but none are quite like BLOODY KISSES. Arguably the best Type O album (their whole catalog, minus the so-so ORIGIN OF THE FECES, is brilliant), BLOODY KISSES was the first Type O album to go platinum, thanks in large part to the epic menace of \\"Black No. 1\\", an eleven minute brood about hair dye. But \\"No. 1\\" wasn't the only good song on this album. It's the masterpiece of the record, but not the only good tune to be found. <br /> <br />The creepy cover of Seals and Crofts \\"Summer Breeze\\", which slows down the up-tempo original version to the ultimate Type O style ballad, is actually clever (there are alternate words than the ones you'll find on here, and they quite funny). You have the nearly nine-minute mini-epic scope of \\"Christian Woman\\", another song that should have been just as big as the predecessor, creepy in the first segment, haunting in the second segment, and during the \\"J.C. Looks Like Me\\" segment, they get heavy and thrash like metal gods. The title track is an epic in its own right, very dark, slow-paced, and menacing. \\"Suspended In Dusk\\" can be found on this version of BLOODY KISSES and its worth the price if you can find the digipack. Sadly, \\"Machine Screw\\", \\"Kill All The ----People\\", and the shorter bits are only found on the standard version. Both versions are actually no better than the other, but the digipack has an advantage by containing \\"Suspended In Dusk\\".  <br /> <br />Either way, you can't go wrong with either version of this masterpiece album. While no classic in its own right, BLOODY KISSES has just about earned that status as the \\"classic\\" Type O Negative album. Selling well over millions of copies by now, BLOODY KISSES is the definitive Type O.

B000000H57|4.0|BLOODY KISSES established Type O Negative as one of the biggest goth-type hard rock groups of all time. While showcasing epic songs and vampiric vocals, KISSES brought Type O into the spotlight, earning them a rabid fanbase and winning some critics over in impressive fashion. OCTOBER RUST turns up the melodic elements of Type O Negative, while the hard thrash mostly takes a backseat here, but make no mistake...this is still a beautifully crafted metal monster. <br /> <br />The two opening tracks, one untitled the other \\"Bad Ground\\" are meant to be sarcastic, as they explain on track #2. But \\"Love You To Death\\" is quite possibly one of the most beautiful love ballads Type O has ever written, and its the more melodic metal that you're likely to find throughout the album. Highlights include the stomping cover of \\"Cinnamon Girl\\"; the incessantly catchy dirge of \\"My Girlfriend's Girlfriend\\"; the semi-creepy haunt of \\"Haunted\\"; and the beautiful yet transparently sick \\"Wolf Moon\\", which is an ode to a woman's monthly friend crossed with a little lycanthropic element. \\"Die With Me\\" is probably the lightest song Type O have committed to album, but it's got some clever and funny lyrics, some sweet but also darkly sarcastic. \\"In Praise of Bacchus\\" features a guest vocal spot from Pist-On's princess Valium, and the duet with her and Peter is quite good.  <br /> <br />Peter was quoted as saying that OCTOBER RUST would showcase a \\"more melodic side\\" of Type O Negative. Throughout most of the album, it is indeed a more melodic and toned down record, emphasizing more melody over thrash and dark metal. While this album might not be to everyone's liking, OCTOBER RUST is the \\"melodic\\" side of Type O Negative.

B00005JNTX|5.0|One of the best movies of 2005, Sin City has action, horror, and spectacular visuals; all you need is a strong stomach and a twisted sense of humor.  I've never read the graphic novels, so I won't be doing a comparison to those, just a review from a happy moviegoer who loves it when style and substance meld together to form a visual treat like Sin City.<br /><br />The plot is simply mayhem and revenge, cops and criminals, in a dark world of concrete and sin.  There's lots of blood, Tarentino style, but most of it is in black-and-white so it cuts down on the squishiness.  The plot is not what you want to buy this movie for.  Buy it for the absolutely spectacular and stylized photography and visuals, and the stunning performances of the cast.<br /><br />Bruce Willis aptly and perfectly plays Hartigan, with his \\"Diehard-deadpan\\" style.  Mickey Rourke is legend in Sin City as Marv, I doubt you will recognize him at first.  The hardest, baddest, meanest, toughest, most vile criminal on the streets, and someone you can root for.<br /><br />Clive Owen (King Arthur) puts his arrogantly serious handsomeness to work as Dwight, a man not to be messed with.  Dwight's Valkyrie, Rosario Dawson (Kids, Alexander) as Gail, gives a stellar (and stimulating) performance in naughty lingerie and a deadly attitude.  Benicio Del Toro (Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas, Traffic) is excellent as Jackie Boy, a bad cop with a bad heart and a bad attitude.<br /><br />Nick Stahl (Bully, Terminator 3) is awesome.  If you liked him in Bully, you will love him in Sin City as Roark Jr, later to become the golem-like yellow freak.<br />And who can ever get enough of Rutger Hauer? (Blade Runner, Flesh and Blood, Ladyhawke, The Hitcher, etc)  Not me.  I love Rutger, and as Cardinal Roark, those deadly, cold, ice-blue eyes are soulfully used.<br />Elijah Wood (LOTR, Final Destination, The Faculty) is excellent as the psychotic, creepy Kevin; a part that you can just tell Elijah had fun with.  Jessica Alba (Dark Angel) can't act, but doesn't have to in the pretty part of Nancy.  Hats off to Michael Clarke Duncan (The Green Mile, The Scorpion King) as Manute and Devon Aoki as Miho.<br /><br />Sin City uses voice-over narration, a third party telling of the action you watch on the screen.  This movie is as good with the sound off as it is with the sound on.  Filmed mostly in black-and-white, the photography is reminiscent of Schindler's List, though 'List' used only one small splash of color and Sin City uses a bit more, the use of color is still limited to such minute and clever spatterings that the impact is still heavily felt.<br /><br />Using over-the-top violence, impossible feats of heroism, strength, agility, and prowess (Watch for Marv's driving scene and Miho's flying archery) and some very black humor, Sin City achieves a horror aficionado's Zen-like state of almost-nirvana.<br /><br />Really, forget the plot.  It's the photography, cast, acting, FX, costumes, stylization, props, and atmosphere that, alone, bring Sin City to five stars and beyond.  Sin City is a must-buy movie.  Enjoy!ave to in the pretty part of Nancy.  Hats off to Michael Clarke Duncan (The Green Mile, The Scorpion King) as Manute and Devon Aoki as Miho.    Sin City uses voice-over narration, a third party telling of the action you watch on the screen.  This movie is as good with the sound off as it is with the sound on.  Filmed mostly in black-and-white, the photography is reminiscent of Schindler's List, though 'List' used only one small splash of color and Sin City uses a bit more, the use of color is still limited to such minute and clever spatterings that the impact is still heavily felt.    Using over-the-top violence, impossible feats of heroism, strength, agility, and prowess (Watch for Marv's driving scene and Miho's flying archery) and some very black humor, Sin City achieves a horror aficionado's Zen-like state of almost-nirvana.    Really, forget the plot.  It's the photography, cast, acting, FX, costumes, stylization, props, and atmosphere that, alone, bring Sin City to five stars and beyond.  Sin City is a must-buy movie.  Enjoy!
B00002MZ4W|5.0|Roughly 3 years after the impressive, although flawed, debut album Tidal, Fiona Apple returns with a powerful, angry gem that perfects everything she failed on with Tidal. This sophomore effort is sheer perfection and one of the best records to emerge from the 90's alternative scene. Here is my track-by-track breakdown of Fiona Apple's When The Pawn: <br /> <br />1. On The Bound-The music on this song is interesting and lilting, sounding almost like something from a carnival. It contains a few musical interludes that are absolutely great, and the chorus is sung with fiery, raw passion: \\"You're all I need!\\" Fiona cries in anger and desperation. <br /> <br />2. To Your Love-Has unique instrumentation, driven by a keyboard, drums, and Fiona's vocals. This song is caustic and powerful, especially the choruses and bridge. <br /> <br />3. Limp-One of the hit singles lifted from this release, and it's fairly short (3:30) and simple, which means it can be boring occasionally. It has a verse, chorus, verse, chorus, musical interlude, and chorus. It's lack of a bridge is disappointing, but it's still an amazing song. <br /> <br />4. Love Ridden-An anemic ballad that would be better if put on Tidal. Pretty and emotional, but nothing special. It's not a skipper, though. \\"Nobody sees when you are lying in your bed,\\" Fiona croons. \\"And I want to crawl in with you/But I cry instead.\\" <br /> <br />5. Paper Bag-I LOVE this song!!! One of my favorite Fiona songs of all time! It's catchy and ingratiate, with stunning lyrics. From here on out, the album just gets better and better. <br /> <br />6. A Mistake-A good song with an interesting arrangement, catchy melody, and good lyrics. <br /> <br />7. Fast As You Can-Once again, great instrumentation, great vocals, and great lyrics.  <br /> <br />8. The Way Things Are-Another favorite. Everything about it is good. Love the piano and drums together. <br /> <br />9. Get Gone-An exceptionally pissed off song that is also one of my favorite Fiona songs of all time. The lyrics and chorus are incredible; the anger in Fiona's voice just oozes through the speakers, as if she's bleeding herself dry. <br /> <br />10. I Know-The perfect closer to the album, a beautiful ballad that is definitely superior to Love Ridden. It's so sad, and the high notes Fiona hits are beautiful.  <br /> <br />When The Pawn is a stunning, angry masterpiece that trounces Tidal in every aspect. With this album, she gets everything right.

B000002BE9|4.0|This album is good, but her other two are vastly superior. Tidal is moody, morose, and sophisticated, but the fact remains that a lot of it is somewhat boring. I do enjoy listening to this when I'm depressed or sad, and it always helps me out. This is a good album, it'a just that she hasn't yet realized her full potential. <br /> <br />The album begins with the heavy beat of \\"Sleep To Dream.\\" This is one of my favorites. It has an awesome melody and the lyrics are spitefully, maliciously good. Occassionally the simple arrangement kind of gets old, but the fact remains that it's one of the standouts on here. <br /> <br />Next we have \\"Sullen Girl,\\" another standout. This song is masterful and haunting, and it's about her rape, so the lyrics are very somber. \\"Is that why they call me a sullen girl...sullen girl?\\" Apple sings in a delicious voice of heartbreaking melancholy. \\"They don't know I used to sail the deep and tranquil sea/but he washed me shore and he took my pearl/and left an empty shell...of me.\\" <br /> <br />The third song, \\"Shadowboxer,\\" is amazing. It has an uptempo, driving beat, and it's catchy while still remaining mature. Its melody is something you will be itching to play, even if you're not a pianist. She's kind of melodramatic in some parts, but you'll get used to that. <br /> <br />Ah, \\"Criminal.\\" What can I say about this that hasn't been said already? Awesome song; an instant classic. One of the songs that defines the angst of the 90's generation. <br /> <br />\\"Slow Like Honey\\" is a slow, jazzy tune, and Fiona sings with a heavy, burning desire. A great song, although some of its appeal wears off after a while. <br /> <br />Track 6, \\"The First Taste,\\" begins with just one note on the piano and Fiona singing. The entire first verse is done like this, then when the chorus hits, an exotic beat kicks in, bringing with it a unique, Jamaican-esque musical background. Her voice in this is beautiful, and despite what others believe, I like the lyrics in this. They paint a pretty picture. <br /> <br />\\"Never Is A Promise\\" is, without a doubt, my favorite song on the album and one of the best songs she's ever written. The chorus is UNBELIEVABLE; she goes incredibly high and it sounds angelic. This is a gorgeous, heartfelt, poignant song that will touch you deeply, I guarantee it. I cry everytime it comes on. <br /> <br />\\"The Child Is Gone\\" is mediocre at best. Nothing special; kinda blah. <br /> <br />\\"Pale September\\" is beautiful. The verses give off an ominous tone, like something is brewing on the horizon. The chorus is lovely and romantic, serenading you. My only problem with this is that the lyrics in the verses don't match the music. <br /> <br />\\"Carrion\\" is an extremely effective closer. The verses are soft and quiet, with Fiona singing in a hushed way against an addictive bassline. The chorus has excellent lyrics and every time it is repeated, it gets louder and stronger, concluding the album with a bang. <br /> <br />Overall, it is a solid effort, although her next two are a whole lot better. Tidal is enjoyable when listened to in moderation, but it can get boring. Despite it's flaws, I recommend it highly to fans of real music.

Also QOTSA's sound resembles nothing of High on Fire, and maybe just a tad bit of Electric Wizard. <br /> <br />Now for the review. <br /> <br />This was Queens of the Stone Age's sophomore attempt at recording. The self-titled was an awesome rock album, and this one takes it a step further. This album feels like one giant party. It rocks out, it's fun, and it's grabbing.  <br /> <br />Queens of the Stone Age have yet to release a mediocre record, but R stands out as the best to select from.

B0000085N4|5.0|1989 was the year in which melodic hard rock was at its peak. Bands like Def Leppard, Guns N' Roses, Aerosmith, and Motley Crue were at or near their peak as their albums were selling millions of copies and pumping out several hit singles. Hair metal was also in full swing as bands like Poison, Warrant, Winger, and Slaughter were riding high on the charts. Another band that found its greatest success that year was a hard rock trio from the U.K. called the Cult. The band's previous releases, Love and Electric respectively, were both very strong and built the band's momentum. Sonic Temple would be the band's breakthrough release as it hit #10 on the Billboard charts and several of the tracks would receive strong airplay. Ian Astbury was one of the most charismatic singers in rock while guitarist Billy Duffy wrote some of the greatest guitar riffs since Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page and AC/DC's Angus Young. While this would be the band's most successful release, listening to the album today makes you wonder how they didn't become superstars. Although several of the songs had hit single written all over them, the closest thing to a hit was \\"Fire Woman\\", which would peak at #46.<br /><br />Every track here is top notch. \\"Sun King\\" is a killer hard rocker, full of Astbury's swagger and Duffy's fiery lead work. The aforementioned \\"Fire Woman\\" would be their biggest hit single and one of the best hard rock songs of the era. How this song didn't hit the Top 10 remains a mystery. \\"Edie (Ciao Baby)\\" is a majestic ballad that is one of the band's best tracks while \\"Sweet Soul Sister\\" is a catchy melodic rocker. While both of these songs barely grazed the Billboard Top 100, the songs still sound great today and are much more memorable than most of the hair metal songs that were becoming hits. The lesser known tracks are also very good. The hard rocking \\"Medicine Train\\" and \\"Automatic Blues\\" as well as the dramatic epic \\"Soul Asylum\\" are awesome tracks and feature a strong Led Zeppelin influence. \\"Soldier Blue\\" and \\"American Horse\\" contain guitar lines that are both heavy and melodic while \\"New York City\\" recalls the raw energy and enthusiasm of the New York Dolls. The remaining track \\"Wake up Time for Freedom\\" is also very good. All told, Sonic Temple is one of the great `80s hard rock albums. Highly recommended.pelin influence. \\"Soldier Blue\\" and \\"American Horse\\" contain guitar lines that are both heavy and melodic while \\"New York City\\" recalls the raw energy and enthusiasm of the New York Dolls. The remaining track \\"Wake up Time for Freedom\\" is also very good. All told, Sonic Temple is one of the great `80s hard rock albums. Highly recommended.    <br />

As a guitarist myself, I'm astounded by what he does on an acoustic guitar playing at high speed and great phrasing too!  Amazing what he accomplished in relative obscurity compared to the modern day guitar \\"gods\\" whose phrasing don't come close to what this guy displays on all the tracks here.  A great album and I highly recommend you try and get a more recently remastered version if you can.

It all builds up to one of the biggest climaxes in rock history.  \\"Won't Get Fooled Again\\", is the ultimate rock anthem form the ultimate rock anthem group.  Beginning with another unforgettable keyboard riff and soon turning into a locomotive of pounding drums and fast paced guitar playing, the song would not be forgotten even into the new millennium. <br /> <br />This ranks right up there with Led Zeppelin's forth album and Black Sabbath's, \\"Paranoid\\" as one of the greatest hard rock albums of all time.  This album is not hard to find so buy it as soon as possible.

B000002J09|5.0|First of all, the reviewer who goes by the alias MTV Supporter has no idea what good music is.  Anybody who thinks 50 Cent and Good Charlotte are better than Led Zeppelin needs to have their brain checked by a shrink immediately. Like-wise anybody who thinks that the only good music is what's played on MTV has no concept of what rock and pop are.  <br /> <br />With that out of the way, this has got to be one of the greatest and most influential albums of all time! Led Zeppelin had already established themselves as the kings of hard rock and early metal with their first three albums.  No one knew what  they were capable of untill this album came out in the early 70's.  The record is a colorful combination of hard rock, pro-metal, folk rock, chamber folk, and pure rock-n-roll.  Every song stands on its own with no support from the other songs at all.   <br /> <br />Zeppelin tries and succeeds at everything here.  The album opens with a heavy metal blues tune called, \\"Black Dog\\".  Robert Plant sings the blues like lines juxtaposed to Jimmy Page's hard rock guitar riffs.  The song ends with an amazing and progressive guitar solo; one of Page's best.  The track, \\"Rock-n-Roll is simply good old-fashion hard rock used in countless car commercials and movies.  Things change completely with the track, \\"Battle Of Evermore\\".  A mandolin driven folk number which sounds like something straight out of Lord Of The Rings or Robin Hood.  Its cryptic lyrics make you wonder what kind of religion or cult the band members were worshiping at that time.  \\"Stairway To Heaven\\", is often considered to be the best rock song of all time(it made number one on my list).  Buiding from a simple acoustic folk ballad to a epic heavy-metal anthem, the song completely rewrites the rules of songwriting and melody composition all in a space of eight minutes.  The track, \\"Misty Mountain Hop\\",  is a driving force song about the dying hippie movement at that time.  Four sticks is a drum driven song with one of Zeppelin's most identifiable guitar riffs.  The song gets its name form the fact that John Bohnam used four sticks on the drums.  The next song is, \\"Going To California\\".  Another acoustic folk ballad,  the song is about leaving an overdemanding lover for a better one in California.  The song speaks of an earthquake happening which, interestingly enough, one occured at the time the band was touring in California.  The closing number is a frightful tune about war and destruction(a subject made popular by the metal band Black Sabbath)  It's another drum driven song with eerie harmonica playing by Plant. <br /> <br />Folk, blues and heavy metal have never so happily shared album space together than on this record.  This ranks right up there with Beatle's Abbey Road and Pink Floyd's Dark Side Of The Moon as the best rock albums of all time.  Yet another record you can't go wrong with.  You don't have to be over the age of forty to enjoy music like this,(I'm only 18 and I have and enjoy almost every Led Zeppelin record ever made).  By Led Zeppelin's forth album(also called Zoso) and you will not be disappointed

0385720920|2.0|With all the hype surrounding \\"Fight Club\\" I made the mistake of picking up \\"Choke\\" thinking it might be a worthwhile read, or that it might keep me in touch with what was \\"happening.\\"  My curiosity was whetted when Mr. Palahniuk came to my local bookstore for a reading and book signing.  The line wrapped around the building, snaked across the street and receded as far as they eye could see.  I should have realized then what I was getting in for: a line for a punk band concert wouldn't have differed; demographically the fans were skewed toward the young, the tattooed and the heavily pierced.  Most stood listening to I-Pods and some held skateboards.  What could these cats possibly be that interested in, I thought.  So I bought. <br /> <br />What can we say about \\"Choke\\"?  On the positive side is Mr. Palahniuk's writing style.  It's clear and full of quick bursts of irreverent energy.  The chapters are short and the narration whips along at a speed agreeable to the attention span of a hamster or an average teenager.  Mr. Palahniuk is a comic writer, and the humor of this work stems from the narration of a man, Victor, who is addicted to sex.  The copious amount of prose spent on describing his lewd acts is essentially, no pun intended, the meat of the book.  He calls his member his dog, and his dog seems to be releasing its \\"little white soldiers\\" on every other page.  Now I believe writing about sex is a fine and noble pursuit, but in this instance I found it boring and redundant by page 50 or so.  Maybe that was the point - we are talking about addiction here.  But that being said, there are some engaging passages for sure - how could there not be with this subject matter. <br /> <br />Now for the book's drawbacks.  One is lack of cohesion.  Other reviews have talked about this, and it cannot be overstated.  The book does not hang together in the classical sense of a novel.  Rather it is driven by a strong narrative voice, which begins repeating itself by the fourth chapter.  A second problem is scope.  If Mr. Palahniuk just focused on a sexaholic and his struggles with that issue, maybe exploring where it came from, we would have a good frame.  Instead, the author chooses to have the narrator cover this Jesus/martyr theme, as well as insanity, as well as assisted suicide, as well as kidnapping, as well as working for a 18th century amusement park, as well as choking for a living.  This choking for a living needs particular attention.  Are we to believe that a man can make a living by choking in restaurants and have people rescue him?  Are we to believe that the people who perform the Heimlich maneuver are really going to then send him checks in the mail?  It doesn't make sense.  And even if we take it as farce, is it at all funny?  Not to this reader.  <br /> <br />In the end, the book swarms out of its own control.  There's a plot twist at the end, which at first made me smile, but upon further contemplation seems cheap and implausible - it was as if Mr. Palahniuk knew his novel was missing something, ie cohesion, and tried to distract the reader with an unearned trick at the end.   <br /> <br />So is this book worth your time?  If you want to read some titillating sex scenes, sure.  If you want an occasional laugh, maybe.  If you are looking for the next literary talent, the artist of the coming generation, look elsewhere.  I don't believe anyone will be reading Chuck Palanhuik in twenty years time.  Scratch that, in ten years time.             <br />

B0007GAERG|5.0|\\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\" project truly is an emancipation for Mariah.  She not only hired completely new management, but she's also shed some of the baggage that she's held onto throughout her 15-year long career: the girly one-word definitive album title, the need to record a \\"Through the Rain\\" / \\"Hero\\" / \\"Make It Happen\\" type song, her tradition of doing one cover song per album, etc.  It also helps that Island Def Jam has undergone crucial changes that are definitely in Mariah's favour, namely the positions that L.A. Reid and Jay-Z have assumed as the heads of the record label.  This project was made possible due to the position Mariah is in now, finally free from anything and everything that had ever been tied to her career since she left Sony.  The stakes were high and amidst all the scepticism, I always had faith that this would be Mariah's moment to prove her naysayers wrong.  And I was right.  This album is headed for both critical and commercial success that far exceeds that of her previous few projects.  Here's why. <br /> <br />Don't be fooled by the list of all-star producers on this album, and think for a second that this will somehow lead to its assimilation into all the generic r&b music out right now (the fact that Mariah co-produces all of her music automatically prevents this from occuring, because the classic Mariah sound is always there).  The album is one of the most refreshing and uniquely crafted bodies of work I have ever heard.  The Kanye-produced track \\"Stay the Night\\", which is an expected throwback to a 70s soul classic, is a vocal masterpiece that has Mariah singing beautiful notes devoid of any melisma and vocal acrobatics.  Both the Neptunes tracks, \\"Say Something\\" and \\"To the Floor\\" are a brand new musical direction for Mariah.  They are subtle and fresh, and although completely different for her, still remain unique in the plethora of Neptunes tracks that have topped the charts in recent years.  Amazing. <br /> <br />Despite the focus on the hitmaker tracks, they aren't even the best on the album.  Mariah works with such underdog producers as The Legendary Traxster on \\"One and Only\\" (where she speed-sings alongside Twista over an ultra-chic beat) and 15-year old newcomer Young Genius, who makes \\"Joy Ride\\" one of Mariah's most passionate and sincere love ballads in recent memory.   <br /> <br />The real hero of this album in terms of production is long-time collaborator Jermaine Dupri.  Not only is he responsible for the first two singles \\"It's Like That\\" and \\"We Belong Together\\" (a stunning return to form for Mariah and undisputably one of the best songs of her career, PERIOD), but he also provided his talents for two other uptempos on the album.  \\"Shake It Off\\" is a clever and sassy freedom anthem, where Mariah sings double-time ala \\"Breakdown\\" and \\"The One.\\"  This is the projected 3rd single and is a guaranteed radio hit with its infectious bounce and lyrical sass (\\"Well at first I didn't know/But now it's clear to me/You would cheat with all your freaks and lie compulsively/so I packed up my Louis Vuitton/Jumped in my ride and took off/You'll never ever find a girl who loves you more than me.\\")  Dupri's final contribution is the 80s throwback \\"Get Your Number\\" which actually features his best imitation of Nelly on the chorus.  Although this song is catchy, well-produced and incredibly fun, JD's whiney hook is likely to distract some listeners from how sexy and playful MC sounds during the verses (\\"I got a pip penthouse with a sick hot tub/We can watch the flat screen while the bubbles fill it up.\\") <br /> <br />While it is pretty hard to choose with such an amazing album, I would say that the weakest track is the Scram Jones-produced \\"Your Girl\\" which is just over 2.5 minutes and is, in my opinion, the song that shows the least amount of lyrical and stylistic growth for Mariah.  Also, \\"I Wish You Knew\\" is beautiful and creative (ultimately, the furthest thing from a \\"weak\\" song), with itsauthentic-sounding live audience and spoken word component.  However, without this, I feel that it would likely slip through the cracks. <br /> <br />What drives this album home is the growth in Mariah's ballads, and their turn towards neo-soul as opposed to melodramatic power love songs.  The moment \\"Mine Again\\" (produced by James Poyser of The Roots) bursts through the speakers, one quickly wishes Mariah had teamed up with him sooner in her career.  The result is absolutely sublime.  A very notable contribution is also made by James \\"Big Jim\\" Wright who prodives Mariah with a raw, organic sound, using only live instrumentation as the background for the ballads.  This puts Mariah's vocals front and center and prevents the \\"over-produced\\" sound of some of her previous ballads (i.e. \\"Never Too Far\\", \\"Bringin' on the Heartbreak.\\")  The \\"Big Jim\\"-produced \\"Circles\\" is lyrically brave, simply gorgeous with some of the best vocals of Mariah's career.  The inspirational song \\"Fly Like a Bird\\" remains true to Mariah's gospel influences, and closes the album both hauntingly and hopefully, with a beautiful, positive message (\\"Somehow I know that/There's a place up above/With no more hurt and struggling/Free of all atrocoties and sufferring.\\")  Her choice to collaborate with these producers was a decision that pushed this album from great to amazing.   <br /> <br />\\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\" truly is an emancipation.  Although Mariah has made some great music in the past few years, this project is easily her best work since the undisputed classic, \\"Butterfly.\\"  The main factor here is GROWTH.  It is the album that showcases the most growth since \\"Glitter\\" (yes, don't believe everything you hear.  This soundtrack was a complete vocal, lyrical and stylistic maturation for Mariah and was highly acclaimed by critics before the movie flopped.  Go figure).  \\"The Emancipation of Mimi\\" picks up where the amazing songs from her recent projects left off (i.e. \\"All My Life\\", \\"Subtle Invitation\\", \\"Clown\\") and has managed to solidify the \\"great\\" status that her recent mediocre tracks simply failed to achieve.  The result is an album that is slightly jazzy, sometimes Hip Hop and consistently soulful.  It is thematically cohesive, as nearly all the tracks remain in the same musical vein of old school while still managing to sound beautifully contemperary.  Quite simply, this is the music I've always wanted Mariah to make.  It is the work of which she was always capable, but needed the right circumstances in order to create.  It is already one of the most critical and initial commercial successes of her career, which also makes it the long-awaited and well-deserved \\"IN YOUR FACE\\" to Tommy Motolla, Virgin Records and all the people who ever doubted the undisputed resilience and talent that IS Mariah Carey. <br /> <br />

B0006A9FKA|4.0|The horror genre has an interesting relationship to comedy. Ever since A Nightmare on Elm Street decided to make Freddy Kreuger a stand-up comedian during his slashing sequences, the dividing line has become more and more blurred, until we reach this film, Shaun of the Dead, which is simulaneously a romantic comedy, a straight-up zombie movie and a send-up of zombie movies. It is very well done, it is very smart. <br /> <br />Because of all it brings to the table, the movie can be enjoyed by just about anyone, but fans of horror films (and zombie movies in particular) will get the most out of the references and allusions. For instance, in one of the first shots of the film, we see Shaun stumbing around his apartment, half-asleep--his walk is 100% \\"zombie-walk,\\" and you'll chuckle if you know what the \\"zombie-walk\\" looks like; when he yawns, making the \\"zombie-moan,\\" it helps to know what it sounds like. <br /> <br />But for all of the in-jokes, the movie never gets too distracted by them and instead concentrates on telling a basic boy-loses-girl/tries-to-get-girl-back story, surrounded by Satan spawn who eat human flesh. <br /> <br />The romance works, the parody works (I'd say Comic *Silver*, as opposed to Comic Gold), the horror kind of works. A worthy example of genre-bending. A fun movie to watch.

This season was one of the most complex and the most rejuvenated. The town of Stars Hollow itself and it's number of looney, but beloved, citizens are just as much a part of the show as anyone else, and I think they got the short shrift in season four. Season five of Gilmore Girls is great television. The girls are definitley back.

B000AP04NI|2.0|Never give away an old DVD while waiting for a new remaster to hit the shelves! I recently gave away my old copy of \\"Oklahoma!\\", and boy do I regret it now!  <br />The first DVD of this movie came out six years ago and was unfortunately not anamorphic. It also had minor problems with shifting color intensity and some \\"flickery\\" scenes, but on the whole it looked quite decent for an early DVD-effort. So, of course I took it for granted that this new 50th Anniversary Edition would boast stellar picture quality. Not so! <br />Well, Disc One with the CinemaScope version looks grand! (This was not available on the old DVD.) But Disc Two, housing the Todd-AO version - the one also used on the 1999 release - is a mess! The colors are slightly faded and dull, and the image is extremely grainy, somewhat dark, and \\"out-of-focus\\" all the way through. This was NOT the case with the old non-anamorphic disc! Even when enlarged via zoom mode to fill my plasma screen from side to side, it looked much more sharp and distinct than the new DVD, with warmer colors and a very bright image.   <br />What happened? Surely a transfer from a 70mm source should be able to look superior to any made from a 35mm print. And what's the point of including a new little featurette where wise people sit and talk about the superiority of Todd-AO, when the rival CinemaScope-version on Disc One looks SO MUCH better? (And by the way, the two Todd-AO featurettes from 1955 and 1958, included as bonuses on Disc Two, look pretty fuzzy too! I saw the first one recently, projected from an original 70mm print on a giant screen, and while the colors had faded miserably, the focus was razor sharp! So there's really no excuse for the boring picture quality on this DVD!) <br />Dear people at Fox: your DVD's for the past four or five years have surely been among the best looking in the business! For this I thank you gratefully. (The new double-disc of \\"State Fair\\" looks absolutely terrific in every little detail! A grand job indeed!) But the new Todd-AO version of my beloved \\"Oklahoma!\\" should be recalled and remastered immediately. The 1999 DVD is proof enough that better material exist in your vaults. Whatever the problem was this time around: It can - and must - be corrected!  <br />Now...while waiting, how can I get my old DVD back without hurting my friend's feelings?
